definition: The histological anatomy of the pilosebaceous unit, divided into specific segments with distinct functional roles.
microscopic: The hair follicle is divided into three segments: 1) Infundibulum: Top portion, contiguous with the epidermis and keratinizes similarly; extends to the insertion of the sebaceous gland. 2) Isthmus: Middle segment extending from the sebaceous gland insertion to the insertion of the arrector pili muscle. This area contains the 'bulge' where follicular stem cells reside (critical for regeneration). Destruction here causes permanent alopecia. 3) Lower Segment (Bulb): Bottom most part, metabolically active and proliferative, responsible for hair shaft production. Contains the matrix and dermal papilla. The follicle is lined by the Outer Root Sheath (pale/glycogenated keratinocytes) and surrounded by a fibrous sheath.
prognosis_and_prediction: Inflammation affecting the isthmus/bulge area can lead to permanent scarring alopecia, whereas inflammation of the bulb (e.g., Alopecia Areata) is often reversible.

definition: A subtype of rosacea characterized primarily by flushing, persistent erythema, and telangiectasias, typically on the head and neck.
clinical: Presents on head and neck skin. Clinically appears red/macular with visible telangiectasias. Typically lacks papules or pustules unless overlapping with other subtypes.
macroscopic: Erythema and telangiectasias on sun-exposed face.
microscopic: High density of pilosebaceous units (indicating head/neck location). Prominent dilated blood vessels (telangiectasias) in the superficial dermis. Sparse perivascular and perifollicular lymphocytic inflammation. Absence of significant spongiosis or follicular pustules.
differential_diagnosis: Other forms of rosacea, telangiectasias from other causes.
prognosis_and_prediction: Chronic condition requiring management of triggers and inflammation.

definition: A fungal infection of the hair follicle caused by dermatophytes invading the deep follicular epithelium and dermis.
clinical: Presents as follicular papules, pustules, or nodules. May not show typical surface tinea changes.
pathogenesis: Dermatophytes invade the hair follicle, often due to trauma (shaving) or immunosuppression/topical steroid use. Deep invasion changes fungal morphology.
microscopic: Suppurative folliculitis (neutrophils within the follicular epithelium). The dermatophytes located deep in the follicle often appear as 'arthrospores' (large, round, yeast-like structures) rather than typical hyphae seen in the stratum corneum, though some septated hyphae may be present. Eosinophils are a frequent component of the infiltrate (a clue to fungal etiology).
ancillary_studies: PASD (Periodic Acid-Schiff Diastase): Positive (highlights fungal cell walls red).
differential_diagnosis: Bacterial folliculitis, Pityrosporum folliculitis, Candida folliculitis.
prognosis_and_prediction: Requires systemic antifungal therapy as topical agents do not penetrate effectively.

definition: A common disorder of keratinization characterized by horny plugs in the hair follicles.
clinical: Follicular centric hyperkeratotic papules, typically on proximal extremities (arms/thighs).
pathogenesis: Abnormal keratinization of the follicular infundibulum.
microscopic: Infundibular dilation with a keratotic plug (comedonal widening). Sparse perifollicular inflammation (mild perifolliculitis). Perifollicular fibrosis that may contain mucin (appearing grayish-blue). Typically seen in skin with lower hair density (trunk/extremities) often involving vellus hairs.
differential_diagnosis: Inflammatory Keratosis Pilaris, Lichen Spinulosus, Phrynoderma (Vitamin A deficiency).

related_figures.legend: Follicular plugging with a triangle-shaped keratin plug in the infundibulum. (Time: 1477s)
Perifollicular fibrosis which appears slightly grayish-blue due to mucin. (Time: 1540s)

definition: An inflammatory reaction occurring when follicular contents (keratin) escape into the dermis.
pathogenesis: Rupture of the follicular wall releases keratin and bacteria into the dermis, inciting a foreign body reaction.
microscopic: Suppurative and granulomatous perifolliculitis. The original hair follicle may be distorted or not fully visible. Granulomas often contain keratin debris or naked hair shafts. Neutrophils are present in the mixed infiltrate.
ancillary_studies: Special stains (PAS, Gram, Fite) may be used to rule out infection, though often negative in sterile rupture.
differential_diagnosis: Infectious folliculitis (fungal, bacterial), Ruptured epidermal inclusion cyst.
prognosis_and_prediction: Resolves with destruction of the foreign material.

related_figures.legend: Debris within granulomatous inflammation indicating follicular rupture. (Time: 2203s)

definition: A spectrum of sterile folliculitis characterized by eosinophilic infiltration.
clinical: Pruritic follicular papules and pustules. Subtypes include Classic (Ofuji - Asian adults), Immunosuppression-associated (HIV/AIDS), and Infantile/Neonatal.
microscopic: Dense infiltration of eosinophils within the follicular epithelium (folliculitis) and surrounding dermis (perifolliculitis). Eosinophils may be diffuse throughout the dermis. The hair follicle is often distorted.
prognosis_and_prediction: Depends on subtype; HIV-associated improved with antiretrovirals.

related_figures.legend: Hair follicle containing a dense collection of eosinophils. (Time: 2454s)
Diffuse eosinophils throughout the dermis in addition to follicular involvement. (Time: 2492s)

definition: A chronic inflammatory disease of the pilosebaceous unit, here demonstrating the comedonal stage.
clinical: Open and closed comedones (blackheads and whiteheads), typically on face, chest, or back.
pathogenesis: Follicular hyperkeratinization, excess sebum, C. acnes proliferation.
microscopic: Large, dilated follicular infundibula plugged with keratin (comedones). Perifollicular inflammation composed of lymphocytes and histiocytes. Fibrosis may be present. Sebaceous glands remain intact (distinguishing from scarring alopecias like LPP). More extensive and deep than Keratosis Pilaris.
prognosis_and_prediction: Can progress to inflammatory/pustular acne or resolve.

related_figures.legend: Deep follicular plugging with perifollicular lymphocytes and histiocytes. (Time: 2802s)

definition: Folliculitis associated with proliferation of Demodex mites, often accompanied by other commensal flora.
clinical: Papulopustular eruption, often overlapping with rosacea.
pathogenesis: Overgrowth of Demodex mites (normal flora) occludes the follicle or induces inflammation. Rupture can release bacteria and yeast into the dermis.
microscopic: Suppurative folliculitis with neutrophils in the follicle. Follicular rupture may be present. Key finding is the presence of organisms within the inflammation/follicle: Demodex mites (large), Pityrosporum yeast, and bacterial colonies. Determining which organism is the primary pathogen vs. bystander can be difficult.
prognosis_and_prediction: Responds to anti-parasitic or antimicrobial therapy.

related_figures.legend: Large Demodex mite visible within the inflamed follicle. (Time: 3121s)
Presence of Pityrosporum yeast and bacterial colonies alongside the inflammation. (Time: 3149s)

definition: A histological variant of rosacea characterized by granulomatous inflammation.
clinical: Firm, yellow-brown or red papules and nodules on the face.
microscopic: Nodular areas of inflammation in a perifollicular distribution. Lymphocytes, histiocytes, and well-formed or vague granulomas with multinucleated giant cells. Unlike ruptured cysts, the inciting follicle is often not visualized directly in the center of the granuloma, though the location is perifollicular.
differential_diagnosis: Lupus Miliaris Disseminatus Faciei, Sarcoidosis, Tuberculosis.
